The architecture of a GPU is characterized by its numerous shader cores, which execute small programs called shaders. <[silence]> Shaders are responsible for determining the color, lighting, and texture of pixels in an image. <[silence]> The high number of shader cores allows GPUs to process vast amounts of data simultaneously, enhancing the speed and quality of image rendering. <[silence]> This design is particularly advantageous for tasks involving complex mathematical calculations, such as those found in 3D rendering and machine learning algorithms. <[silence]>

Floating-point operations are a critical aspect of GPU functionality, enabling precise calculations required for rendering detailed graphics. <[silence]> GPUs are equipped with dedicated hardware to perform these operations efficiently, ensuring high performance in graphics-intensive applications. <[silence]> The ability to handle floating-point calculations with speed and accuracy is a defining characteristic that distinguishes GPUs from other processing units. <[silence]> This capability is leveraged not only in gaming but also in scientific computing and data analysis. <[silence]>
